June 23
Received 10 August 1921
1921
Faisal arrives in Basrah today. We've thrown our die + the
next few days will show whether it's a winning number.
His adherents anticipate that his coming will be the sign for
a great popular ovation - Heaven send it may be so for it will
immensely simplify matters for us. Meantime there can be no
question that it is regarded with anxiety by
the magnates Refers to influential people in Iraq. . On
Monday we had a strong deputation from Basrah bringing a
petition in which they asked for separate treatment for the Basrah
area. They were ready to accept a common king, + in conversation
they declared that Faisal would suit them, but they asked that
Basrah might have a separate legislative assembly, a separate
army + police service + raise + spend its own taxes making a
suitable contribution to the central administration. They came
to me on their way to Sir Percy + asked me to support their
request. I said No, whatever
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
decided would have my
loyal support as a government servant, but until that
decision was given I must
exercise excercise
my private opinion which was
that what they asked was not in the interests of the country
as a whole + would not prove to be permanently in their own
interests, though it might be to their immediate advantage to keep
out of the distractions attendant on the founding of a new state.
With that they went to Sir Percy who gave them a sympathetic
hearing but said in general terms that he could not conceal
from them that
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
wanted to see a united 'Iraq. However
a large degree of local autonomy would be consistent with
that end + a compromise on these lines should be considered.
Sasun Eff. who had a talk with the leading man of the
deputation, Abdul Latif Pasha Mandil, asked him whether
Basrah were ready to take over Nasiriyah, which was
part of the old Basrah
wilayat Refers to an administrative region of the Ottoman Empire. , + when Abdul Latif
replied in the negative, he pointed out very reasonably
that the Basran petitioners were shirking all the difficulties
+ reserving for themselves only a wealthy + peaceful

of doors on druggets spread on the grass. I expect it
was rather heavy going but I didn't put it to the test.
I sat out + talked to people, supped with Sir Percy +
came home with Mr Tod at midnight, while the gay
Lady Cox danced till 4 a.m!
I must
tell till
you that
Shaikh Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
Khaz'al
has abandoned
his candidature for the throne, of the 'Iraq, with a
beau geste declaring that Faisal was a candidate he
considered him infinitely more suitable than himself + would
henceforth devote all his efforts to supporting him. I hear
he is being as good as his word; he met the Baghdad
deputation at the station when they arrived + has
actively participated in preparations for Faisal's reception.
I expect Faisal will come to terms with the Basrah magnates
+ satisfy them that Basrah will receive fall consideration.
Mr Cornwallis is with him - a tower of strength + wisdom;
I've sent him a letter explaining how the wind blows
throughout the 'Iraq + as soon as he comes up here I shall
be able to keep him posted in local politics. Oddly
enough Mr Philby, who is strongly anti-
Sharifian Term referring to things or people related to or supportive of the Sharif (a title used to describe those - usually royal - claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad), in this case Mr Philby is opposed to the idea of a system headed by a Sharif.
+
has really been doing a good deal of harm by
openly advocating a republic (very wrong of him)
has also gone down to Basrah "on business". I hope
it means that he wants to make his peace with
Faisal.
Already the whole town is flying the Sharifian flag.
I saw it today flying on every other shop in the bazaar.
The intention is good but the flag heraldically bad - I
don't know if you know it?
The red triangle
covers over the black + green which
is colour on colour
red
black
green
white

2
enclave which nobody doubted could be easily run +
administered. Meantime we get wails from the opposite
party in Basrah saying that the petition does not
represent the majority, that signatures to it were got by
intimidation etc. I don't myself believe that their complaints
are true; at any rate the petition represents the views of
practically all the solid merchants + landowners.
I saw Sasun in the afternoon at the Library Committee
- I've been elected President of the Baghdad Public
Library - + he came back to my house for a talk. In
the evening I met all the world at a most successful
party given by
the Garbetts Sir Colin Campbell Garbett and his Wife, Lady Marjorie Josephine Garbett. . Their garden + the terrace on
the river were carpeted + lighted with lamps, not to
speak of a full moon, + everyone of importance in the
town was there. We spent a most agreeable + friendly
evening + talked no politics, though the air was heavy
with coming events.
The
Reception Committee Committee for Faysal's reception in Iraq.
got their programme through the
Council on Monday + the Mutasarrif, Rashid Beg, a
strong Sharifian, brought it in to me for Sir Percy' s approval
on Tuesday. What they wanted to know was what part Sir
Percy was going to take + above all whether we would
provide a guard of honour. I promised to get the reply
as soon as possible. But things don' t go as quickly as that
+ yesterday morning, Wed., Rashid Beg turned up again +
said they had had no answer. Later in the morning I
arranged that he +
Majid Beg al Shawi
should come
in + have a personal interview. Meantime Nuri Sa'id,
who had been in Basrah, had seen me the previous
evening + told me about the popular demonstration.
He thought it might result in an immediate

acclamation aclamation
of Faisal as King + asked me anxiously
whether we should mind that. I answered in suitable
terms that we only wanted to know the opinion of
the country + didn't mention how very well such a
turn of affairs would suit us. All this I reported
to Sir Percy that night at a ball given by Lady
Cox + it may have partly influenced his answer
to Rashid Beg next morning - anyway Faisal is to
have his guard of honour both at Basrah + here.
I had a fantastic evening on Tuesday. Mme Talib + her
children were leaving that night for Basrah on the way to
Ceylon to join Talib + I thought I really must go to the station
to see her off. Sir Percy agreed that it would be much better
+ I set off to the station at 9 p.m. in my evening clothes.
I was very glad I had gone for several of Saiyid Talib's
friends or supposed friends made acte de presence + it
wouldn't have looked well if Sir Percy had not been
represented. I saw her comfortable installed + then waited
to do the same by the wife of the Heir Apparent of Persia
for his party was also travelling that night to Basrah
for India + Europe. If he catches trains in Europe the
same way he does here he won't often get any where. He
was half an hour late arriving at the station + even
then was in no hurry to get himself packed in.
+ dying to get out of Mohammadan countries to somewhere
where she can drop her veil. Having disposed of his
+ her women + eunuchs I set off to Lady Cox's
ball which was given at the Sport's Club right away
north near
Mu'adhdham. The location referred to here is uncertain. It may be a district of Bagdad.
It was a beautiful night
with a moon + a cool wind + they danced out

5
is therefore wrong, isn't it?
June 26. I left off writing to go out to dinner with the Shaik
of Chabaish - it's near the Hammar Lake - who is here in
his capacity as Minister without portfolio. He is a wealthy
man + has just bought a very expensive motor which he sent to
fetch me to dinner. Really the combination of tribal shaikhs +
motor cars of the latest pattern is one to which I find it
difficult to adjust myself. Shaikh Salim has considerable ability
+ even more ambition. He's a strong supporter of the idea of a
republic mainly, I think, because he believes he might become
President - a fantastic notion. It was a pleasant party, all
my intimate friends such as 'Abdul Majid Shawi + Fakhri
Jamil, but Lord! such a hot night! A burning wind which
scorched us as we sat on Shaikh Salim's balcony on
the river bank. Yesterday we had news of Faisal's arrival
in Basrah + an excellent reception, heaven be praised.
The news came from Mr Philby whom by a master stroke of
policy Sir Percy sent down to Basrah to meet Faisal. I
can't help hoping that Faisal will make a conquest + that
Mr Philby will come back an ardent Sharifian. Faisal has
now gone off to Najaf + Karbala + gets here on Wed 29th.
Half my mornings have been spent in receiving visits from
the Mutasarrif or exchanging messages with him on the
telephone about the reception + festivities here. We have got
it right at last I think. Mosul also is coming forward.
A large deputation of all the leading people came down
here last night + Nuri Sa'id, whom I saw this
morning, tells me that their line of argument is that
they can't think why there's such division of opinion here
+ that far the best course is to proclaim Faisal
King at once. This is extremely satisfactory for Mosul

6
up to now has been very sticky + we have had gloomy
messages from Mr Nalder to the effect that our
Sharifian policy would never be accepted. The
magnates now declare that they couldn't come out
into the open before because they thought that Mr
Nalder wouldn't like it. The truth is that from
top - or near the top - to bottom our English
Civil Service hasn't got the right perspective + but for
Sir Percy' s calm assurance that the thing would go
through I should often have despaired of it myself.
Nuri Sa'id came in one night last week to tea + said
that if they hadn't had my constant help they could
not have carried on, + I replied that I stood fast
all the time in Sir Percy 's unswerving purpose. But
I have been useful to them all the same these last
weeks + I'm glad I've been here.
I'm told that Naji Suwaidi is in favour of a
mandate rather than the proposed treaty because
a mandate gives us more authority! Faisal wants a
treaty I know, so probably that's the way it will
work out, + for my part I think it s quite immaterial.
You can't run a mandate without the good will of the
people, + if you've got that it doesn't matter whether
it's a mandate or a treaty, but what rejoices
me is the fulfilment of my dream that we should
sit by in an attitude of repose + have them
running up our front door steps to beg us
to be more active! I know there are difficulties
ahead; the rub will come when we have to help

7
them against their own extremists, but nothing is
insurmountable so long as they are not straining
against our rein. You understand, these men with whom
Sir Percy + I are working are bitterly anti-
panislamic Collins defines panislamic as, 'of or relating to the doctrine that all Muslims should be united under an Islamic state.'
+
bitterly anti-Turkish. They regard us as their best
hope in winning through to
pan - Arabism Collins defines pan-Arabism as, 'the principle of, or support for, or movement towards, Arab political union or cooperation.' , + so we
are here in Mesopotamia but I fear in the future
we shall be hampered by our support of
Zionism Collins defines Zionism as, 'a political movement for the establishment and support of a natal homeland for Jews in Palestine, now chiefly conserned with the development of the modern state of Israel,' or 'a policy or movement for Jews to return to Palestine from the diaspora.'
in Palestine + the French in Syria, neither of which
is consistent with a pan-Arab policy.
This morning, Sunday, I went for a long ride
with Mr Tod before breakfast + tonight we
have a swimming party on his launch which should
make a well-spent Sunday.
I forgot to
tell till
you that Marie hadn't after
all cracked the bone + she is now nearly well.
My wardrobe has benefited by her enforced inactivity.
This week I've had letters from you + Mother dated
May 25, yours with 2 delightful photographs of Bill.
He must be most engaging.
Goodbye + bless you both, including Maurice.
Your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude

On His Majesty's Service.
23 June
10 August
1921
Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
ARAB BUREAU, BAGHDAD.
